div1.head: Report to the Provisional Governor, by Carlos J. Finlay, November 1, 1908
div1.p: Havana, November 1, 1908.
TO THE PROVISIONAL GOVERNOR.
Havana.
Sir:

In compliance with instructions received through the Ad-
viser of this Department, I have the honor to transmit herewith
the reports of the Administrative Officer (Jefe de Despacho) of
the National Sanitary Department, Dr. E. B. Barnet, and of the
Local Health Officer of the district of Havana, Dr. José A. Ló-
pez del Valle, relative to the work done in their respective sec-
tions.
NATIONALIZATION OF THE CUBAN SANITARY DEPARTMENT

As was to be expected, the beneficial influence of the nation-
alization of this Department manifested itself soon after the
rules prescribed in your important Decree No. 894 of August,
1907, were carried into effect, by a marked decrease in the num-
ber of deaths caused by preventable diseases, such as are listed
in Bertillon's group of “General Diseases”, as well as under
the headings of “Diarrhoea and Enteritis under two years of
age”, for the control of which constant vigilance on the part
of the health officers to provide good milk for the children in
their respective districts, is an essential condition. In Cuba yet
another cause of death must be included among the preventable
ones, namely; Tetanus in new born infants. I have on former
occasions called attention to the large number of deaths record-
ed under this heading in Cuba, and it is undoubtedly due to the
lack of aseptic precautions in the management of the umbillical
cord. In point of fact, several years ago, at my solicitation, the
presence of the tetanus bacillus was found in five out of six sam-
ples of the cotton-wick (pabilo) which, since time immemorial
has been used by incompetent or ignorant assistants for ligating
442
the cord of new born infants. In order to remedy this evil, the
Sanitary Department has been receiving from a reliable firm of
the United States a regular supply of carefully prepared pack-
ages containing, in perfectly aseptic conditions, all the material
needed for successive dressings of the cord, with ample instruc-
tions for the unitiated regarding its employment. These pack-
ages are freely distributed to poor expectant mothers or their
midwives, and most of our drug stores have them for sale.

In comparing the death returns from the three aforesaid
classes of preventable caused, during the twelve months from
October 1st, 1907 to September 30th, 1908, in the whole terri-
tory of the republic, with those corresponding to the previous
similar period (October 1st, 1906 to September 30th, 1907),
we find:

For “General Diseases” 7230 deaths as againts 7860, for
“Enteritis under two years” 4174 as against 5889, and for “Te-
tanus neonatorum” 762 as against 899, showing a total of 2502
lives apparently saved, which may fairly be credited to the im-
proved conditions which have prevailed in the whole territory
in consequence of the nationalization of all the sanitary services.
THE PREVALENCE OF YELLOW FEVER SINCE OCTOBER 31, 1907

The total number of cases of yellow fever occurring in the
republic since the date of my last report has been 79, with 29
deaths. That report which described the occurrence of this dis-
ease from the date of re-infection of the territory of the republic
in October, 1905 to October 31, 1907, gave an account of the epi-
demic outbreak at Cienfuegos in August, September and Oc-
tober, 1907, and of its control by the measures taken under the
immediate charge of Captain H. D. Thomason, U. S. A., who
was appointed a special commissioner of the Department for
that work. Thirteen sporadic cases occurred in Cienfuegos be-
tween the 1st of November, 1907 and the 21st of January, 1908.
In the nine months since that date, there has been no re-appear-
ance of the disease in Cienfuegos. The last occurrence of yellow
fever in the province of Santa Clara was in the city of Santa
Clara where six cases occurred between the 9th and 18th of Feb-
ruary, five of them being soldiers of the American garrison. In
the province of Camagüey, for the first time, a small focus de-
clared itself in the town of Ciego de Avila near the Santa Clara
boundary. Ciego de Avila is one of the stations of the Central
443
Railroad where passengers going both ways stop to take a meal,
and the infection may have been brought by some ambulatory
case traveling on the train. Three cases occurred, the patients
being attacked on October 31st, November 6th and November
13th, so that the mosquitos causing these cases were probably
all infected from a common source, none of the cases being sec-
ondary. Captain Thomason was temporarily transferred to Cie-
go de Avila, and by his vigorous and comprehensive measures
of fumigation and the prevention of mosquito breeding, the
focus was promptly and completely extinguished, so that no
other case occurred in Ciego de Avila or the province of Ca-
magüey. A case occurring in Cienfuegos on December 5th, was
found to have come from Santiago de Cuba during its pe-
riod of incubation, and evidence was thus afforded of the exist-
ence of a focus in the latter city. A very careful sanitary inspec-
tion of Santiago, however, failed to localize the focus of infec-
tion, or to discover any other case until the 7th of January. Cap-
tain Thomason was transferred to station in Santiago and given
supervision of the city, and his management proved so far suc-
cessful that between December and June when the infection was
finally stamped out,, only five sporadic cases developed, one in
each of the months of January, February, April, May and June.
To this focus in Santiago, however, must be credited the infec-
tion among the miners in the Daiquirí district, where twenty
cases appeared in June and July, besides one in a neighboring
mine (Concordia) belonging to Firmesa. Strict quarantine by
land and sea having been established and energetic fumigations
with close vigilance, under the direction of Major Fauntleroy,
M. C., U. S. A., as Special Commissioner, extinguished this focus
so that no other case has developed there since the 31st of July.
Finally at Antilla (northern coast of Oriente province), another
case having been infected in the last week of August, the same
measures were taken, including quarantine. After this, the only
other case recorded was a non-immune Spaniard, found sick
with yellow fever at Havana on the 7th of September. Since this
last date, in view of the radical measures that have been adopted
and the care with which all non-immunes with fever are
watched, there is every reason to believe that the yellow fever in-
fection has now been stamped out. With reference to our success
in our present yellow fever campaign, I beg respectfully to call
the attention of the Provisional Governor to Captain Thomason's
444
remarkable record as Special Commissioner of this Department
at Cienfuegos, Ciego de Avila and Santiago de Cuba.

Our experience in the last three years, during which the
Cuban Sanitary Department for the first time, has been called
upon to deal with a serious yellow fever infection, has brought
to light two important improvements in our former methods for
fumigating infected buildings, and for controlling the breeding
of mosquitoes in open water containers from which the access of
those insects can not well be prevented.

The old process of preparing buildings for fumigation by
papering all the openings and chinks in the interior, inclusive
of the roof when the latter is not mosquito proof, was open to
serious objections. First, the time involved, and secondly, the
chasing out of the mosquitoes into the open by the men working
inside, displacing the furniture, etc. Instead of this, Captain
Thomason, M. C. U. S. A., when he took charge of the infected
district of Cienfuegos last year, suggested that these objections
might be obviated by simply covering the whole building or
several of them together, with an air tight covering of canvas.
And this has proved so advantageous that it has now been gen-
erally adopted whenever the necessary material can be provided
without delay.

For preventing mosquitoes from breeding in open water
containers, an old friend and collaborator, Dr. Claudio Delga-
do, suggested as the result of his personal observations in Unión
de Reyes, in collaboration with the Local Health Officer, two
years ago that this might be done by introducing in the contain-
ers small fresh water fishes, which he asserted, would greedly
devour the larvae and pupae. His suggestion was strengthened
the following year by independent observations in the British
West Indies, especially at Barbadoes, and when Dr. Delgado's
suggestion was given a fair trial, the results were found most
satisfactory. In the city of Camagüey, in particular, where in
the absence of a regular water supply, the generality of the in-
habitants rely on rain water collected in very large earthen-
ware jars of which several are kept in each house, the employ-
ment of small fish, vulgarly called “guajacones” (Cyprinodon-
tidi, gen. Gambusia and girardinus, Poey), has proved most suc-
cesful in the hands of the Local Health Officer, Dr. McMillan;
so much so, that whereas the proportion of houses free from
mosquito breeding places had previously been only fifteen per
445
cent of all the inspected houses, after the introduction of the
guajacones, the number free from breeding places has been in-
creased to 98 per cent.
TUBERCULOSIS

For the control of tuberculosis, a National Sanatorium, “La
Esperanza”, which has been in contemplation and for which
an admirable site had been chosen under General Wood's gov-
ernment, has now been erected in conformity with the most im-
portant modern requisites.

For the district of Havana also, a tuberculosis dispensary
has been expressly constructed with a well organized service,
which was very much needed in this district. It will be described
in the report of Dr. López del Valle, Health Officer of this
district.
Very respectfully,

(Sig.) CARLOS J. FINLAY,
Chief of Sanitation.
